I am a graduate student at Indiana University – Bloomington.
I will eventually be posting about my research, however for now it will be mostly random ramblings I have about economics, coding, sports and life within the blog.

title: Joseph Westenberg

content:
Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: Third year paper topic for Jordan River Conference.
title: Redistricting and Economic Outcomes

content:
As an aspiring user of #econtwitter, I figured I would investigate how to embed tweets within a blog post.
Utilizing the hugo academic framework, I can directly put .html code within the body of the blog’s code. Twitter has a nice built in feature to simply extract html code for the tweet. It should look something like this.
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Been experimenting with Hugo Academic and hosting through github. Happy to say I finally have an up and running site <a href="https://t.co/NK2vLKMo9U">https://t.co/NK2vLKMo9U</a> and dare I say it was actually enjoyable to make!</p>&mdash; Joe Westenberg (@jmwestenberg) <a href="https://twitter.com/jmwestenberg/status/1255621184365920258?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">April 29, 2020</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> When including that code in the blog we get the following:
Been experimenting with Hugo Academic and hosting through github. Happy to say I finally have an up and running site https://t.co/NK2vLKMo9U and dare I say it was actually enjoyable to make!
— Joe Westenberg (@jmwestenberg) April 29, 2020 This was a fairly simple solution and ideally I’d like to figure out how to get something that looks more like a tweet. Supposedly you can also embed a live twitter feed on a personal webpage. Both of these tasks are getting added to another day’s to-do list.
summary:
As an aspiring user of #econtwitter, I figured I would investigate how to embed tweets within a blog post.
Utilizing the hugo academic framework, I can directly put .html code within the body of the blog’s code. Twitter has a nice built in feature to simply extract html code for the tweet. It should look something like this.
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Been experimenting with Hugo Academic and hosting through github.
title: Embedding Tweets in Markdown

content:
I started the journey with creating a website this past winter. With the stay-at-home orders and being back in Wisconsin, where its still rarely above 45 degrees, I decided to actually put the finishing toucheson it and experimenting with how to publish it online.
While I knew about and had been using Hugo Academic since the winter to slowly create content, I just recently learned that with github, you can host your own website for free! Being an economist though, I have tonote that the website isn’t actually free, I put many hours into debugging, but now I am finally at a point to make it public!
summary:
I started the journey with creating a website this past winter. With the stay-at-home orders and being back in Wisconsin, where its still rarely above 45 degrees, I decided to actually put the finishing toucheson it and experimenting with how to publish it online.
While I knew about and had been using Hugo Academic since the winter to slowly create content, I just recently learned that with github, you can host your own website for free!
title: My First Post

content: Special thanks to Dr. Schaffer who was my undergraduate advisor, encouraging me to pursue academic research and graduate education.
summary: Paid jobs providing more time flexibility may appeal to workers who have primary responsibility as a caregiver for young children or for sick, handicapped, or elderly adults. However, in some jobs, workers who are given this flexibility may be less productive per hour than workers who commit to a fixed work schedule chosen by the employer. These two realities may lead employers to offer, and caregivers to accept, lower paying jobs that come with more time flexibility. Since caregivers in the United States are disproportionally women, this may help to explain the lingering gender wage gap in the U.S. Data sets were combined from the 2015 revision of the Occupational Information Network (O*NET) and the 2003 through 2015 March Current Population Surveys to analyze this issue. The combined data set includes extensive information on workers’ average hourly earnings and personal characteristics along with 407 characteristics of their occupations. Log wage regressions were used to show that the data are not consistent with the Time Flexibility Hypothesis when applied to occupation categories.
title: Time Flexibility, Women’s Wages, and the Gender Wage Gap
